awd_titl_txt: Workshop: World War II Anthropology: Austrians and Germans in Poland, Japanese in Asia, and the Search for Survivors (AAAS, Pacific Division Mtg., U Cal-Riverside, June 2014)
awd_abstract_narration:
Roger Christianson of Southern Oregon University will oversee an international symposium on the role of German, Austrian, and Japanese anthropologists in annexed territories (in Eastern Europe and Asia) during the first half of the twentieth century through the Second World War. The research will aid in our understanding of the role that anthropological science played in colonial and wartime Europe and Asia. They will discuss the roles these anthropologists played in consigning Polish people from immediate death to mindless labor, the records they created, how the records were used to find Polish survivors after the war, and what transpired once survivors were found. Also to be discussed will be research relating to the investigations of Japanese anthropologists in Asia, beginning with the colonization of Taiwan in 1895 through military expansion during World War II.  

This anthropological research documents little known information about the role of anthropologists during wartime, how their services were used to support German and Japanese ambitions, and how anthropologists today search for survivors.

This symposium will be conducted before scientists, graduate students, and high school students at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Pacific Division, annual conference at the University of California, Riverside. Abstracts of the presentations will be published.

por.por_cntn:
Although the extremes of human cruelty by the Germans and Japanese during WWII are widely known, there is yet much to be learned from records of the victims kept by the German and Japanese governments. Also, it is important to bring details to light in order to refute those who would deny that the events actually occurred.

 

The symposium was structured to discuss 1) the role of the Institut für Deutsche Osterbeit (IDO) in Poland during World War II and the records created by the IDO Section on Race and Ethnicity, how those records were used to find survivors of the War, survivors' recollections of the Section’s activities, and how the science from the records were used to document Polish migration patterns and 2) what the Japanese anthropologists carried out on Taiwan and Korea during Japan’s colonial period and during the War.

 

There were approximately seventeen attendees in the audience, which consisted included professional members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) including several members of the Pacific Division of AAAS, students from a variety of universities including the University of California, Riverside, and members of the general public. Three of the panel members, including the chair, were from the United States. Those participating from outside the United States came from Japan, Korea, and Poland. At least one member of the audience came from a region (Podhale) in Poland that was being discussed at the symposium.

 

As a result of bring brought together for this symposium, several outcomes among the panel members have been identified:

 

1. Drs. Gretchen Schafft and Kyung-soo Chun are working together on two projects. a) Chun has published a book on Japanese anthropological research in New Guinea during World War II. He will begin research on China and the Nanking massacre. Because Japanese anthropologists received their training in Germany before World War II he will be working with Schafft to see if there is a link between Japanese treatment of Chinese in Asia during the War and the German treatment of Jews in Europe. b) Schafft and Chun will also be working on giving a presentation regarding discrediting history. The topic concerns events of the past that bring shame on a group of people, such as the Holocaust and Germans and massacres in Asia by the Japanese. This study involves the displacement, denial, and the shifting of historical stories to make them seem heroic instead of horrible. In this scenario, incidences of heroism are stressed while the actual acts of cruelty and violence are diminished.

 

2. Dr. Patycja Trzeszczynska-Demel is planning to invite Dr. Alicja K. Lanfear to visit Poland and join her research at Jagoellonian University as a physical anthropologist to work on contemporary methodological questions on possible collaboration between physical and cultural anthropology.

 

3. Dr. Schafft is attempting to have German publishers translate her book, “Commemorating Hell,” which contains remarks made at the AAAS-PD symposium. Additinally, Drs. Schafft and Chun are combining the use of anthropological research and historical evidence during World War II to present a more global picture of the actions of German and Japanese anthropologists in their role of supporting ethnic cleansing in Europe and Asia.

 

4. Professor Trzeszczynska-Demel is planning with her colleagues to continue research into the work of the IDO, focusing on the Lviv district.

 

5. One of the presenters from Poland may have her talk published in a United States newsletter for members of the “Highlander” group from the Podhale region.
